name: The Intercept
theoryOfChange: Journalism as an instrument of civic action to empower the public to demand a better world from institutions.
zakatClaimEvidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly) (Source: https://theintercept.com/about/)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or clearly state whether donations are zakat-eligible.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 17/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: Expenses ($9,519,616) exceed revenue ($5,597,043) by 70% - may be drawing down reserves

score_details.score_summary: The Intercept Media Inc shows good impact and limited alignment.

zakat.claim_evidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly) (Source: https://theintercept.com/about/)

all_citations.claim: The Intercept Media Inc is a non-profit news organization focused on investigative journalism and advocacy.
The organization accepts general charitable donations and sadaqah to support its mission.
The organization reported total revenue of $18,961,623 and a program expense ratio of 71.7%.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score due to its high financial efficiency and transparency, though its advocacy-focused mission results in a lower alignment score for traditional donor profiles.
areas_for_improvement: Alignment with specific Muslim donor priorities is currently low
Impact measurement is focused on capacity building rather than direct service delivery

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is considered medium as the organization focuses on broad advocacy and systemic accountability rather than specific community-based interventions [1]. While its mission to expose injustice may resonate with many, it lacks specific features tailored for Muslim donor fit [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates moderate impact by dedicating a 71.7% program expense ratio toward investigative reporting and media production [3]. While it maintains high data confidence and strong financial health with 8.3 months of working capital, its primary output is capacity building through journalism rather than direct social services [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Intercept Media Inc is a non-profit newsroom dedicated to investigative journalism and holding powerful institutions accountable through adversarial reporting.
strengths: Maintains a strong working capital reserve of 8.3 months
High fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.08 per $1 raised
baseline_narrative.summary: The Intercept Media Inc operates as a non-profit news organization focused on investigative journalism, documentary filmmaking through Field of Vision, and podcasting to expose corruption and injustice [1][3]. The organization reported a total revenue of $18,961,623 and maintains a program expense ratio of 71.7% [3]. Donors can support these efforts through various sadaqah-eligible charitable giving methods [2].

all_citations.quote: The Intercept is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit news organization.

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score due to its high financial efficiency and transparency, though its advocacy-focused mission results in a lower alignment score for traditional donor profiles.

areas_for_improvement.context: The current <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 71.7%</cite> is lower than the typical 70-80% benchmark for high-performing charities.
There is a <cite id="1">lack of consistent beneficiary data</cite>, making it difficult to assess the cost-effectiveness of its journalism.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization provides audited financial statements and maintains high transparency through Candid.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization mitigates financial risk through a very high working capital reserve.
risk_factors: <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 71.7%</cite> is below industry standards
<cite id="1">Small board of directors (4 members)</cite> limits governance diversity
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="3">relatively high administrative overhead</cite> and a lack of direct service impact metrics.

alignment.explanation: The organization is <cite id="2">sadaqah-eligible</cite> but lacks specific signals for Muslim donors, such as zakat policies or focus on underserved Muslim communities.
alignment.improvement: Adding a dedicated giving page that <cite id="1">clarifies the social impact of journalism</cite> within an Islamic ethical framework could improve donor fit.

credibility.explanation: The Intercept is highly credible due to its <cite id="1">Platinum Seal of Transparency</cite> and <cite id="3">detailed annual filings</cite>. However, its board governance is considered <cite id="1">minimal with only 4 members</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization could <cite id="1">expand its board size</cite> to improve independent oversight and governance.

impact.explanation: Impact is focused on capacity building through <cite id="1">investigative reporting and filmmaking</cite>. While outcomes are measured, the <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 71.7%</cite> suggests higher administrative costs than peers.
impact.improvement: The organization should <cite id="1">publish consistent beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for a more rigorous assessment of its cost-per-impact.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Measured outcomes without external evaluation

rich_narrative.headline: The Intercept Media Inc is a non-profit newsroom dedicated to investigative journalism and holding powerful institutions accountable through adversarial reporting.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize civic accountability and believe that investigative journalism is a critical tool for social justice and exposing institutional corruption.
donor_motivations: Support independent media as a pillar of social change
Prefer funding long-term systemic change over direct aid
Want to support high-transparency organizations with Platinum ratings
giving_considerations: Impact is systemic and long-term rather than immediate and individual
The organization maintains very high cash reserves
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill zakat obligations or those who prefer direct humanitarian relief with clear cost-per-beneficiary metrics.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects that while the organization tracks <cite id="1">outcome metrics</cite>, it lacks a formal third-party evaluation of its journalistic impact.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The Intercept creates impact by producing high-quality investigative journalism that informs the public and pressures institutions to reform.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence in journalism helps donors understand how specific stories lead to policy changes or legal accountability.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: The organization has a <cite id="1">$19 million funding gap</cite> to reach its full investigative capacity.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="1">8.3-month capital reserve</cite> and unique focus on <cite id="1">adversarial journalism</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Larger scale and more established impact metrics
similar_organizations.name: ProPublica

strengths.detail: The organization maintains <cite id="1">8.3 months of working capital reserves</cite>, providing a robust buffer for long-term investigative projects.
The Intercept demonstrates strong fiscal discipline, spending only <cite id="1">$0.08 to raise every $1</cite> in charitable contributions.
The charity has earned a <cite id="1">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, the highest level of disclosure for non-profits.

strengths_deep_dive: The Intercept's financial model is characterized by high efficiency and stability. Its <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.08 per $1 raised</cite> is significantly better than many advocacy-based non-profits, ensuring that the vast majority of donor support is directed toward its journalistic mission. Furthermore, the organization’s <cite id="3">$18.9 million in annual revenue</cite> is managed with a focus on long-term sustainability, evidenced by its <cite id="1">8.3 months of operating reserves</cite>. This financial health allows the newsroom to pursue complex, multi-year investigations without immediate risk of insolvency.
rich_narrative.summary: The Intercept Media Inc is a non-profit newsroom founded in <cite id="3">2014</cite> that specializes in <cite id="1">investigative journalism, podcasts, and documentary filmmaking</cite>. The organization operates with a mission to <cite id="1">expose corruption and injustice</cite> by holding powerful individuals and institutions accountable through adversarial reporting. In the 2023 tax year, the organization reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $18,961,623</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="3">$18.7 million in charitable contributions</cite>. Beyond its core reporting, the organization manages specialized programs such as <cite id="1">Field of Vision and the Snowden Archive</cite>. While it maintains a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 71.7%</cite>, its financial health is bolstered by significant liquidity, holding <cite id="1">8.3 months of working capital</cite> to ensure operational stability. The Intercept also engages in strategic grantmaking, recently providing <cite id="3">$280,000 to Drop Site News Inc</cite> to support independent media ecosystems. As a non-religious media entity, its activities are classified as <cite id="2">sadaqah-eligible</cite>, offering a platform for donors interested in civic transparency and social justice.
